title: 3d Architectural lettering
content:
Can someone ID the font used on these 3d architectural letters? One is a closer view. If not exact, any suggestions for something close.

Thank you.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [west.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20060604052027/http:/typophile.com/files/west.jpg) | 17.4 KB |
| [west-all.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20060604052027/http:/typophile.com/files/west-all.jpg) | 15.18 KB |
author: evan

comments.content: Thanks but that’s not right. For example, the S on my sample has no serifs on the ends, but Baskerville does.

[Berling](http://web.archive.org/web/20060604052027/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/berling/) is also close but not exact, especially the lower serifs on L and E, there is the strong possibility that the signage is based on a “font” that is specific to the medium, I assume there are limits to which metal can be created in three-dimensions and that a letterform would be designed to cope with the material and production. However, I’ve been wrong in the past.  
Tim
Furthermore, signage lettering is often not based exactly on a specific font, or at least not one that is commercially available.
